narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned so much about Brazil and its place in the world, especially the ways it is similar to and different from the US and how its political history is unique in Latin America. Very eye-opening as someone who was never taught anything about the country before college.
More insight into the history of Brazil and recurring themes

History of Brazil taught me the broad strokes of Brazilian history from Portuguese colonization in the early 16th century to the present day. The course also covered the major themes of Brazilian history and how they continue to impact the country today.
Overview of Brazilian history since 1500s; half of the course is Brazil until independence, the other half is post-independence Brazil
overview of Brazilian history

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The readings were a little excessive sometimes. Most weeks I had to look at the list of readings, decide what looked most important, and just skip some of the other stuff. That said, the readings were certainly engaging, helpful, and insightful, and I enjoyed them thoroughly.

This class had great lectures, well-chosen readings, and a grading system that I liked. I appreciated the open-book, 24hr exams and how open-ended the paper was. However, information about those assignments seemed to be always given at the very last minute, so I often felt like I didn't know what was going on or what would be expected of me. Unfortunately, this lack of organization does a disservice to the professor and the topic.
I thought the course could focus more on modern history (which we essentially only covered in the last 2 lectures) and a lecture on current events, which essentially wasn't covered.

History of Brazil was well-organized to cover half a millennia of Brazilian history in a single semester. Lectures were divided both by time period and theme. Professor Schwartz was passionate and extremely knowledgeable about the subject matter, and my TF was communicative and made sections engaging. 

One aspect of the course which could be improved is its consideration of language. Professor Schwartz would often use both English and Portuguese words for various terms relevant to Brazilian history. This could get confusing, particularly in regards to the topic of race, which is conceived of and described differently in the United States and Brazil. Our lectures and readings were very helpful to understanding the conception of race in Brazil, but discussion about how the language used can influence understanding was largely limited to section.

Strengths: extremely flexible and accommodating, Prof Schwartz is a really friendly and nice guy, TFs were also great. 
Weaknesses: would be great if they said upfront that they would provide PDFs of some of the books online (at least the Diacon, which we didn't read much of anyway) so I wouldn't have spent money renting all of them

This course gives you a great survey of Brazilian history, while allowing you to explore a specific topic of your own interest in the final papera great balance between breadth and depth. I felt I left the course feeling a lot more knowledgeable about Brazil (since many enter the course knowing next to nothing about this country that is so often overlooked). I would highly recommend to take this with Professor Schwartz. His lectures were always very engaging.
Prof Schwartz and the TFs were the biggest strength, they were clearly interested in what they were talking about and made the entire class that much more enjoyable

Strengths: Professor Schwartz was a g. The TAs were great, especially Polly. The flexibility on the papers allowed me to hone in on a topic that truly interested me.

Weaknesses: None at all
I enjoyed this course and learned a lot about Brazilian history
strength: primary source readings
Great course; don't change anything
Communication about assignments should be streamlined and organized. It was confusing at times to know the requirements and deadlines of assignments.

Strength: lectures are very good, Schwartz is a great lecturer, very open to office hours
Weaknesses: it might be helpful to have something written on each slides, even if its just the time period. It was sometimes difficult to write down the important info/ spell things correctly

I really enjoyed this course. It's a straight-up history class with no weird stuff or formats. I'd strongly recommend it. If I were to change one thing, it'd be to extend the amount of time talking about modern Brazil. Alternatively, restricting the timeframe of the course to end in 1960 or so would also work.
Super personal class, despite the fact that 40 students were taking it. Professor and TFs really put their time in.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I found it helpful that the lectures, review sessions, etc. were often recorded and uploaded to Canvas. I also appreciated that the exams were open-book and we had 24 hours to complete them.
I thought everything succeeded

Virtual lectures were live but available as recordings after the fact, while sections required synchronous attendance. In section we used the breakout room and whiteboard features to stimulate learning. Exams were effectively adjusted to the realities of online learning.
Lecture course, so pretty well adapted for virtual format
everyone was super accommodating and understanding, and overall there was a mutual understanding that online learning was rough for everyone.
The virtual lecture was successful
Everything was well-adapted to pandemic conditions

I believe the lecture format worked nicely but powerpoints should contain some information. I believe that will be helpful in cases where recording is not done or if people have bad internet and cannot hear the professor.
I think both the lectures and section were well run for zoom.
Please keep the live virtual lectures. So much better than prerecorded.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class was super interesting and I highly recommend it. The readings are very engaging and the papers and exams are designed to provide you with an opportunity to showcase what you have learned. If nothing else, the opportunity to learn about the history and culture of Brazil was highly rewarding.
I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to learn more about Brazil - but if disorganized classes bother you, you might want to skip this one.
Yes, provides a good foundation for learning more about Brazil

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to any student at all interest in history or Latin America. Prior to taking this course I know nearly nothing about Brazil, and now I feel like I have a broad understanding of why Brazil is the way it is today.

Yes - very accessible, total overview. Be prepared to spend a lot of time on pre-independence (which might be good because you might be able to apply to have it count as a Pre-Industrial history for the History Major requirement)
for sure! Brazilian history is extremely interesting and has a lot to offer for any History person

If you're interested in Brazil/Latin America at all, then 100% yes. Schwartz is one of the leading scholars on Brazilian culture/history in the US, so when he lectures it sounds more like storytelling than regurgitating random facts (like some other history professors).
I would recommend - I took a lot away from this class
yes
yes
Yes, great class. Going to lecture was more like listening to an interesting history podcast than anything else.
Yes! Schwartz is a very good lecturer and the topic is quite interesting. I learned a lot this semester!
Yes, the professor was great and it was a really interesting introduction to Brazilian history.
Yes, take it if you're looking for a straight-up history class. Nothing weird going on here.
Yes! Especially in a remote setting, the lectures are to the point and the readings brief. Great instructors too.
